Dear Ms. Shores:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection
Section law.
Description • (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law,
1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that an agency foster care worker knew that the foster
mother was using marijuana with minors.
Investigation The agency Chief Administrator was contacted via telephone
on 01/30/2025 and informed of the complaint. Chief
Administrator provided agency staff contact information relevant to
the investigation.
The Complainant was interviewed via telephone on
04/02/2025 and reiterated the information documented in the
complaint.
Foster Parent 1 was interviewed via telephone on 03/28/2025
and 04/02/2025. Foster Parent 1 reported she has two children
that resided in her home as foster care children until July 2024
when they were adopted by her. They are hereafter referred to as
Adoptive Child A and Adoptive Child B. Adoptive Child A and
Adoptive Child B are part of a large sibling group. Three siblings,
Foster Child 1, 2, and 3, are under the care of Relative A. Foster
Child 1 is 18 years old, Foster Child 2 is 16 years old, and Foster
Child 3 is 20 years old. Foster Child 3 resides at a local college.
Foster Parent 1 reported that sibling visits have occurred between
Adoptive Children A and B and Foster Children 1, 2, and 3. Foster
Parent 1 reported that sibling visits would occur at the home of
Relative A and she would transport Adoptive Child A and B to and
from the visits. Foster Parent 1 reported on one occasion when
she picked up Adoptive Child A and B from a sibling visit at the
home of Relative A her children smelled of marijuana. Foster
Parent 1 reported this occurred sometime in April 2024, and she
was concerned about minors smoking marijuana in the home.
Foster Parent 1 reported Adoptive Child A and B both reported to
her that marijuana use is occurring in the home. Foster Parent 1
reported another incident when she picked up Sibling A from the
home of Relative A to transport him to a relative’s funeral. Sibling
A resides in Florida and visits the home of Relative A on occasion
to visit his siblings. Sibling A is a sibling of all the children named
2

in this report. Foster Parent 1 reported when Sibling A entered the
car he smelled heavily of marijuana. Foster Parent 1 also reported
Sibling A smelled strongly of cologne which she believed he was
using to hide the smell of marijuana.
Foster Parent 1 reported during a May 1, 2024, Family Team
Meeting (FTM) she raised her concerns about marijuana use in
the home of Relative A and she did not want any further sibling
visits to occur in Relative A’s home and suggested they occur in
public places or at her home. Foster Parent 1 reported Staff 1, the
Saginaw DHHS foster care worker for Relative A’s home and the
foster children who reside there, responded that he has not
witnessed marijuana use in the home of Relative A and therefore,
it is not a concern. Foster Parent 1 further reported Staff 1 had
said he had never smelled marijuana or seen it’s use when he
would conduct visits. Foster Parent 1 reported she felt her
concerns were not being treated seriously by Staff 1 or the
Program Supervisor who was also present at the FTM.
The agency Program Manager was interviewed via Teams
Meeting on 04/02/2025. Program Manager reported she was not
aware of the concerns raised by Foster Parent 1 during the
05/01/2024 FTM. Program Manager reported the Program
Supervisor and Staff 1 attended the 05/01/2024 FTM as there was
friction between Foster Parent 1 and Relative A regarding sibling
visits and the agency wanted this resolved in order for sibling
visits to occur with regularity. Given the concerns raised by Foster
Parent 1 during the 05/01/2024 FTM, Program Manager was
asked should a complaint have been filed with Central Intake.
Program Manager confirmed twice that a complaint regarding
safety concerns in the home of Relative A should have been
called in to Central Intake. Program Manager reported that
something does not have to be observed in order to file a
complaint. Program Manager used sexual abuse as an example
that would not be observed but would warrant the filing of a
complaint if allegations arose. Program Manager was asked if a
safety plan was developed for the home of Relative A and she
responded she was not aware of one.
Staff 1 was interviewed via Teams Meeting on 04/02/2025.
Staff 1 reported he is the foster care worker for Foster Child 1, 2,
and 3, all of whom reside in the home of Relative A. Staff 1
recalled the concerns raised by Foster Parent 1 during the
05/01/2024 FTM. Staff 1 reported he has never observed
marijuana use in the home of Relative A and has never smelled
marijuana in the home. Staff 1 did report he has smelled incense
3

in the home. Staff 1 reported Relative A uses marijuana but does
not use it in the home and around the children. Staff 1 reported
the foster children in the home have never reported marijuana use
in the home. Staff 1 reported he had no reason to suspect
marijuana use was occurring in the home. Staff 1 was asked that
given what Foster Parent 1 was reporting, should that information
warrant the filing of a complaint with Central Intake. Staff 1
responded since he had never smelled or observed marijuana use
in the home the decision was to create a safety plan instead of
filing a complaint with Central Intake. Staff 1 was asked to submit
the safety plan to this consultant, but reported he did not have it,
and Program Supervisor should have it and referred her for that
document.
Case Manager was interviewed via telephone on 04/02/2025.
Case Manager works for Family Community Services, a private
agency, and is the foster care worker assigned to the home of
Foster Parent 1. Caseworker reported she attended the
05/01/2025 FTM. Caseworker reported Foster Parent 1 had raised
concerns about marijuana use in the home of Relative A and
because of this did not want sibling visits to occur there.
Caseworker further reported Foster Parent 1 was concerned that
minors in the home were using marijuana. Caseworker reported
that Program Supervisor asked her at the FTM if she was
concerned about marijuana use in the home of Relative A and she
confirmed that she was, Caseworker reported she asked Program
Supervisor if anything was going to be done about the reported
marijuana use and Program Supervisor responded they do not
have those concerns therefore this would not be followed up on.
Case Manager reported Program Supervisor then stated she and
Staff 1 would create a safety plan.
Program Supervisor was interviewed via Teams Meeting on
04/02/2025. Program Supervisor is the supervisor for the Saginaw
County DHHS foster care program and is the supervisor of Staff 1.
Program Supervisor reported she attended the 05/01/2025 FTM in
an effort to resolve friction occurring between Foster Parent 1 and
Relative A. Sibling visits had been interrupted for a short period of
time and the agency wanted them to continue regularly. Program
Supervisor reported the agency has never had any concerns
about Relative A and remarked she is an incredible relative
parent. Program Supervisor reported she felt that Foster Parent
1’s allegations were retaliatory against Relative A. Program
Supervisor was asked that based upon Foster Parent 1’s
concerns about the home of Relative A should a complaint have
been called in to Central Intake. Program Supervisor responded
4

that it seemed that Foster Parent 1 was making those allegations
to “get back” at Relative A. Program Supervisor also reported
concerns about the foster children having to go through an
investigation and that it would not be good for them. Program
Supervisor was asked about a safety plan, and she did not know
of one.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
FOSTER CARE FILE:
• Family Team Meeting: A Family Team Meeting dated
05/01/2024 was reviewed. A social work contact for the
FTM documents the concerns raised by Foster Parent 1
about marijuana use in the home of Relative A and she
feels that her children are not safe there when visiting
siblings because of marijuana use.
• Social work Contacts: In home contacts of Relative A’s
home from January 2024 through September 2024 did not
document any concerns about the home.
• Investigation: An investigation of Relative A’s home, dated
02/27/2025, was conducted by another DHHS Worker.
There were no findings.
• There was no documented safety plan within the case file.
A review of the rest of the file did not add anything to the
investigation.
Analysis
The Program Manager acknowledged that a complaint regarding
the alleged marijuana in Relative A’s home should have been filed
with Central Intake.
Staff 1 and Program Supervisor were informed of Foster Parent
1’s concern during the FTM on 05/01/2025 regarding marijuana
being used in the home of Relative A. Foster Parent 1 was
concerned about the safety of her children while at sibling visits at
Relative A’s home. Staff 1 and Program Supervisor did not contact
Central Intake nor file a DHS-3200 based upon this information.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license.
